article_title: San Antonio surgeon highest-paid Texas doc
article_text:
San Antonio surgeon highest-paid Texas doc

Photo: Express-News File Photo / San Antonio orthopedic surgeon Stephen Burkhart was paid nearly $24...

A dozen physicians in Texas were paid more than $1 million by medical device companies, pharmaceutical companies or group purchasing organizations from August 2013 through the end of 2014, according to data released by the federal government as required by the Affordable Care Act.

article_metadata.description: A dozen physicians in Texas were paid more than $1 million by medical device companies, pharmaceutical companies or group purchasing organizations from August 2013 through the end of 2014, according to data released by the federal government as required by the Affordable Care Act.  Dr. Stephen Burkhart, president of The San Antonio Orthopaedic Group, is one of the world’s foremost experts on shoulder arthroscopy, a minimally invasive surgery done to repair shoulder dislocations or torn rotator cuffs.  CMS collects and publishes the fee data for its Open Payments program to promote transparency in financial relationships between the health care industry and providers like physicians and teaching hospitals, the federal agency said in a report to Congress this month.  The payments are generally for royalties and licensing, consultation fees, speaking fees, research activities, gifts or to cover dining or travel expenses, CMS said.  “Disclosure of the financial relationships between the industry and health care providers is not intended to signify an inappropriate relationship, and Open Payments does nothing to prohibit such transactions,” said CMS’ report to Congress.  The surgeon, who has more than 40 patents in the United States and an equal number overseas, said the bulk of the payments revealed in CMS’ data go to physicians like himself who invented medical products.  To ensure propriety, Burkhart said he does not receive royalties for sales of any medical devices he invented that are used on any of his patients or anyone treated by his colleagues at The San Antonio Orthopaedic Group.  Seven of the dozen Texas physicians receiving more than $1 million from medical device companies, pharmaceutical companies and group purchasing organizations are orthopedic surgeons, ProPublica’s analysis shows.
article_metadata.author.name: By Peggy O’Hare, Staff Writer
